description:
Citrullus lanatus, commonly known as the watermelon, is a trailing vine plant that belongs to the Cucurbitaceae family. It is an annual herbaceous plant that typically grows up to 3 meters in length and produces large, round to oblong fruits.

The leaves of Citrullus lanatus are deeply lobed and covered with coarse hairs, giving them a rough texture. The flowers are yellow and have five petals, and the fruits are typically green on the outside with a red, juicy, and sweet flesh on the inside.

Watermelons are known for their high water content, which can range from 90% to 92% of the total fruit weight. They are a rich source of vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants, including vitamins A, C, and B6, as well as lycopene, an important carotenoid compound.

Citrullus lanatus is believed to have originated in Africa and is now cultivated worldwide, primarily in warm and tropical regions, for its edible and refreshing fruits. It is a popular summer fruit, often consumed fresh or used in various culinary preparations, and has also found applications in the cosmetic and pharmaceutical industries.
